title: Lm8uu Y Carriage for Prusa Mendel

description.text: I don't have the equipment to do precision drilling for the lm8uu holders, and adding a belt tensioning system to the wooden carriage eats up Z printable space. So my solution is to design my own Y carriage with build in belt tensioning. Please check out V2 of this here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12979

The stl files with the makergear suffix are for Makergear Prusa Mendel and should be a drop-in replacement for their wooden y-carriage. This is the set that i have printed, tested and am currently using. The stl files without suffix are sized for standard Prusa Mendel. However due to me not having a standard Prusa Mendel, they have not been printed or otherwise tested in anyway by me.. so you will be at your own risk if you decide to give them a try. Also enclosed are the scad files, you can change the dimension to whatever you need in there.

A simple project to get young minds introduced to 3d printing and 3d modeling software. A pen holder is a simple yet useful first time project for beginners and can be uniquely customized too people wants and needs. Read for some 3D design tips and a "MakerEd Project" for using this type of 3D design in a classroom! V1= weird cube shape
V2= Circular

These pen holders where designed by using 3d modeling software called Creo parametric.
To begin the rough size of the pen holder was determine and a block that size was placed. Using the tools on Creo material was removed from the block to create a cool design for a pen holder. Some basic things to keep in mind is how wide the pens are and how big of a hole you need to put them it.

Project: Pen holder Objectives:
-students would be expected to learn how to create basic shapes and manipulate them in a way to create a "pen holding device"
-students would be expected to learn how to create their own personalized designs and how to use 3d modeling software
-students would be expected to learn how 3d modeling machines work on a basic level Audience: For grade 6-8 range, no prior skill need only the ability to operate a computer or ability to communicate your ideas to some else that would operate the computer if they are unable to (disabilities, injuries, etc). Preparation:
-Students will need access to computers with applicable 3d modeling software such as Creo Parametric, autocad, etc.
-No previous 3D design experience is required for students
-A teacher that is familiar with the 3d modeling software being used in order to provide help if the students have any questions
-This can be done in groups or alone Steps:
1)Firstly in their groups or alone students will start the brainstorming process to starting thinking of their design
2) once they have an idea several rough sketches should be made to smooth out rough details
3) Once the students have a rough sketch designed that has been approved by a teacher they are to create it using 3d modeling software
4) the designs can be adjusted as need on the 3d modeling software if the students realize that their design will not work for some reason.
5) once the students are done the 3d modeling on the computer the teacher will review the model and point out any errors or parts that might not print well
6) then with the help of the teacher the students will create and stl file to print
7) they can then watch there create be printed in front of there eyes then come back in a few hours once it is completed.
8) once the "pen holder" has completed printing the students will test them out and comment on how they could have made their design better or what works well about their design as it is. Result: By the end of the activity students should have a better understanding of how 3d printing works and what it is capable and should be able to create basic designs on 3d modeling software. In order for grading students could be graded on a formal report after printing saying how they came up with their idea, what features they wanted in their design then how they could have made their design better etc. Marks could also be given for the ability to do group work/ how well they get a long with others

Everyone who has used a 3-D printer before knows that the orientation of a print can greatly affect its ability to handle a load.  Because of the layering process used in 3D printing, objects tend to be stronger when pulled perpendicular to the layer build up direction vs when pulled parallel to it.  This design will allow students to study the difference in tensile strength of 3D printed material parallel and perpendicular to the "grain" of the print
Notes: Different materials and layer heights will yield different results. Experiment and optimize your material!
This tensile specimen is built per ASTM E8 to ensure they can be used in a standard tensile testing machine

Project Objectives: The objective of this process is to observe and understand the different tensile strengths of 3D printed material loaded in perpendicular directions. This is a study in orthotropic materials. Audiences: This project would be best suited for advanced high school-university level students interested in material science, and 3D printing Preparation: The only major piece of hardware needed for this project is a tensile testing machine which is available in most universities that have an engineering department. Students should have an understanding of what tensile strength is as well as stress/strain curves. Students should experiment with various different 3D printable materials and layer heights to see what effects they have on tensile strength. Steps: Student will print multiple test specimen in both orientations and test them till failure to find the stress strain curve and total tensile strength of the parts. Students can then compare the different results they get for perpendicular vs parallel loading. Results: Students should walk away with a deeper understanding of orthotropic material and an improved ability to design load bearing 3D printed objects

I thought I'd upload the solid library I use when I design physical things like cases and enclosures for DIY electronics projects.  
I've used MCAD quite a bit but ended up writing my own solid libraries for a few projects I was working on. Maybe they'll be useful for you too.

author: cleve535

title: ZMR250 Arm with Motor Protection shorter longer and normal with different hole spacing only for 22xx Motors
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This are my new interpretation of ZMR Arms with
-motor protection
-and its stronger (look at the pictures) In one of the pictures you can see two circles. The inner circle (27mm) is like an 22xx motor and the outer circle (33mm) is to demonstrate how much space is to the motor protection. Because different hole spacing in circulation I have even uploaded the four most common. The total length is 123mm, 117mm or 105mm. The length from motor mount middle to first frame mount hole middle is 86mm, 80mm or 68mm. And in this versions there are only one motor mounting dimensions. -The shorter version is intended for only 5 inches propeller
-The mean length, also standard version, is like standard arms and on a standard ZMR normally you can mount 6 inches propellers
-The longer version is intended for special ZMR buildings like an choped ZMR. With this length you have no problems in any situation with 6 inch propellers You can see in the picture which is A and which is B (frame mount dimensions M3) (in the Filename is missing a comma 12 5 is 12,5 ...) Motor mount dimensions:
15,8mm - 19,2mm M3 (2204 2206 motors)
Inner hole dimension:
9,0mm (2204 2206 motors) Not for 3D printing but for CNC (normaly 3mm carbon) You can send an appropriate company and then gets the right part. My Favorite in Germany is actually https://noblish.com DEUTSCH:
Das ist meine neue Interpretation der ZMR Arme mit
-Motorschutz
-und Verstärkung (in den Bildern zu sehen) In einem der Bilder kann man zwei Kreise sehen. Der innere Kreis (27mm) ist groß wie ein 22xx Motor und der äußere Kreis (33mm) ist zu Demonstration wieviel platz bis zum Motorschutz ist. Wegen der verschiedenen Lochabstände die im umlauf sind, habe ich die 4 meist verbreiteten Maße hochgeladen. Die Gesamtlänge ist 123mm, 117mm oder 105mm. Die länge von Motormitte bis zur Mitte erstes Frame Montageloch ist 86mm, 80mm oder 68mm. In diesen Versionen gibt es nur eine Motor Montagegröße. -Die shorter Version ist nur für 5 Zoll Propeller gedacht
-Die mittlere Länge, also standard Version, ist wie die original Arme und an einem Standard ZMR kann man normal auch 6 Zoll Propeller montieren
-Die longer Version ist gedacht für spezielle ZMR Umbauten wie bspw. eine Chop ZMR. Mit dieser länge hat man in keiner Situation Probleme mit 6 Zoll Propellern Im Bild kann man sehen welches Maß A und B ist (Frame Montagelöcher M3). (Im Dateinamen fehlen Kommas 12 5 ist also 12,5 ...) Maße Motormontage:
15,8mm - 19,2mm M3 (2204 2206 Motoren)
Maß Innenloch:
9,0mm (2204 2206 Motoren) Nicht für 3D Druck gedacht sondern für CNC (normal 3mm Carbon). Man kann z.B. die entsprechende Datei einer geeigneten Firma zusenden und bekommt dann das passende Bauteil. Mein aktueller Favorit dafür ist https://noblish.com

This is a replacement for the weak fixations of the bottom plate.
They integrate a linear bearing which do a great job.
PLA linear bearing are very very quiet.
If they are too tight just put a 8mm drill to adjust the diameter.
The holes are made for M3 3*35mm. Fixations de remplacement pour le plateau de l'imprimante.
Les fixations d'origine bougent trop facilement, et les roulements font beaucoup trop de bruit.
Si les fixations glissent mal sur le tube, faire glisser le tube plusieurs fois jusqu'à ce que ça coulisse facilement, ou faire quelques passages (gentils) avec une mêche de 8mm.
Les trous sont prévus pour un boulon M3 de 35mm.

I designed and laser cut this heart shaped box for my Mum for Mothers Day back in 2013. It uses kerf bends / living hinges to bend the sides around the heart shape. Designed for 3mm plywood though the whole design can likely be scaled to suit other thicknesses of materials. Add your own text to the top and bottom surfaces for a personal touch.
The Lid is held closed by the fit of the cut-out which is glued to the underside of the lid top (see fourth photo). Alternatively magnets could be hidden inside the box and a thin metal plate bonded to the lid to hold it closed.

This was a 6th grade social studies project. The students were learning about the Aztec and Mayan civilizations. Each student designed a structure in the style of one of those two great cultures.
Students were allowed to select any structure they wanted to model. In the future key structures from a city like Tikal or Tenochtitlan can be modeled by having each student design one of the buildings.
Most models were printed at reduced size to save time.
Completed this project with another 6th grade classes, added their models.
NGSS

This was a 6th grade social studies project. The students were learning about the Aztec and Mayan civilizations. Each student designed a structure in the style of one of those two great cultures.
Students were allowed to select any structure they wanted to model. In the future key structures from a city like Tikal or Tenochtitlan can be modeled by having each student design one of the buildings.
Most models were printed at reduced size to save time.

• Students used the Internet to research structures and artifacts from the Aztec and Mayan civilizations
  • Students decided on a structure of artifact to model in 3D using the website Tinkercad.com
  • Models were created by combining geometric shapes on Tinkercad. Two dimensional images found on the Internet can be converted to SVG and imported, or inserted into a Google Drawing and traced, then converted to SVG and imported. This method can be used to create engravings and glyphs.
  • Models were checked by the teacher for print-ability and corrected, if necessary.
  • Models were printed
  • Students showed their models to their classmates and explained their function, or cultural significance.

Objective Design and print a structure or artifact in the style of the Mayans or Aztecs Audience This was a 6th grade project. The students had limited experience with Tinkercad and 3D printing. Preparation This project was part of a social studies unit that compared the Aztec and Mayan civilizations. Students drew Venn diagrams showing the similarities and differences between the two cultures. Steps
  • Students used the Internet to research structures and artifacts from the Aztec and Mayan civilizations
  • Students decided on a structure of artifact to model in 3D using the website Tinkercad.com
  • Models were created by combining geometric shapes on Tinkercad. Two dimensional images found on the Internet can be converted to SVG and imported, or inserted into a Google Drawing and traced, then converted to SVG and imported. This method can be used to create engravings and glyphs.
  • Models were checked by the teacher for print-ability and corrected, if necessary.
  • Models were printed
  • Students showed their models to their classmates and explained their function, or cultural significance.
    • Results This project was successful. The student created models are included here. Some of the students had some trouble printing their models because the parts were not solidly connected, or because of overhangs.

How to Transform your 3D Printer in a CNC MILLING MACHINE There is a good tutorial on transforming and using your 3D printer into CNC machine. "We can finally presents you a tutorial on how to modify our 3D printer K8200 to
transform it in a perfect CNC milling machine, to be used for the production of
PCBs, by incision. In addition, we also show you the procedures to obtain the G-Code
file required for the machine to perform the contouring of the slopes and the drilling of
the base: this starting from any Gerber file or from a project made with EAGLE software."
electrokit.com/productFile/download/6139
pdf file.
https://github.com/kmkolasinski/AwesomeBump - AwesomeBump is a free and open source program written using Qt library designed to generate normal, height, specular or ambient occlusion, metallic, roughness textures from a single image. gEDA is a software suite with schematic and PCB layout editor. http://www.gpleda.org/

Geeetech Delta Rostock Mini G2S I'm using it with Geeetech Delta Rostock Mini G2S 3D printer. The printer has bad precision due to bad design. Bit mounted onto rotary tool will move + - 1 millimeter at slight resistance of routing material. What program does the milling machine support?

    https://github.com/martymcguire/inkscape-unicorn (extension for Inkscape.)
    https://github.com/villamany/3dpBurner-sender/releases
    • Change firmware in printer before modifying to milling machine?

It's an mp3 player cover.
I've made it to:
1) keep earphones' cable not entangled
2) protect player's buttons from unintended pressing
3) control player in my pocket without need to see it's buttons
4) keep player's screen from scratching by metal earphones' cases
My mp3 player model is Ruizu X11.
Earphones model is Astrotec AX35.
This cover is not universal. If You like the idea, You need to redesign this thing for your player and earphones.

RepRap

HE3D X-I3

Rafts:

No

50%

Notes: ABS.

I printed this cover divided in two parts, bottom with slots and top, then glued them together with acetone. You can use sketchup file to divide it different way or combine parts to print as one piece.
This cover required much work with knife, files, hot air gun (to tune and tighten up and down parts to player).
Bottom part has holes for earphones. The holes are also needed to get earphones out of their slots, and they need to be big enough for your fingers.
Bottom part has beveled edges to match cable length. These bevels can be calculated (I think), or use trial and error method.

description.text: I made the body in multiple pieces, in Adobe illustrator, and the head is made on the egg bot,from inkscape.  The .svg files and .ai file of all types are uploaded. Please note that depending on the file the size of acrylic needed may vary and the eggbot's .svg file works best.

Each section of the body is cut on a 40 watt laser together on on piece of 9 mill acrylic at 8 speed 100 power and 5000 frequency, run the acrylic cut twice to cut through.   The eggbot use a black ultra thin sharpie and the fake ping pong balls for the surface.  Any ball could be used but ping pong balls work he best for the size of the body.  Each piece can be glued with acrylic glue and the head with epoxy of a small amount of hot glue, too much melts the ping pong ball.

text = Margie

This IS the droid you are looking for! (With apologies to Obi-Wan.) Pose him by moving his arms and swiveling his head! Store small items in his hollow body! Remove him from the base to set him free! Engrave your own message using customizer! All parts are printable with no supports! What more could you ask from an Android Guy? Customizer lets you generate individual parts or a simple single-print platen that contains all the parts in one shot. There are also two preview modes: exploded view and assembled view. (Those are not meant to be printed but show you what the assembly looks like.) (The sample image shows four Android Guys that were made as gifts for my son's Android team at a summer program called GSET in 2012.) There are numerous improvements over the versions on which this is based:
  • The arms are movable to pose your Android Guy. No glue is needed for assembly of the arms.
  • Proportions are much closer to the real Android logo.
  • You can add your own text message to the little guy's chest (uses thing:16193 Write by HarlanDMii).
  • Customizer support with multiple parts views.
    • Print one today and enjoy your own adorable Android Guy!

Use customizer to choose a text message, size, and other parameters.  The parts menu lets you select individual parts, or a full production platen with all parts. It has two modes not meant to be printed: "exploded" and "assembled" just so you can preview the little guy in all his glory.  
If you have trouble inserting the arm, then heat up the hole in the body for a few seconds using a butane lighter just until it gets a little soft. Then quickly insert the arm and wait half a minute for it to cool/harden.  
Glue the legs to the body if desired. If you want, you can glue the legs onto the base, or leave them loose so you can remove the base.  
The head comes off so you can use this as a container.

Notes: I use a 5mm raft for the adapter but no supports. You could print supports for the over hang if you want. I put a bit of a taper in the part to make it printable without supports and it can be done. You might have a stray strand or 2 on the first layer of the over hangs put those can be trimmed and you still have a usable part. I use a 100% infill because this part needs to be strong. I will be hooking it up to a 49cc gas powered drill. Tested this part with PETG and Poly Carbon. Neither was strong enough to do the job.
Add a small bungy cord or other piece of something to attach to the drill in case the adapter comes loose .... don't want to lose your auger to the bottom of the lake.

This is a printable model of the Asteroid 4 Vesta, one of the largest asteroids in the main belt between Earth and Mars.  The Dawn probe is currently in orbit and its images are the source of the model.  NASA has not as of yet released a 3d model, so this is a bit of a scoop.  Vesta is a partially differentiated body and hence has a rounded shape, although much of its south pole was removed in a collision with another body.

This was an interesting lesson in how to develop small space body shapes when there was no model released. Skip this if you think it's tl;dr, but it does give some ideas about how to print globes of space bodies. My first approach was to take the released orbit view (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Vesta_Rotation.gif), break it down into individual frames using ImageJ and then submit the individual sequential shots to an online point cloud generator such as my3dscanner. This created distortion at the poles where there is less data, but with some mesh editing in Meshlab could be printed, although it required a lot of work. This version is based on using the ApplyMeshUVN command in Rhino3d - using the projected map of Vesta (found here) http://dawn.jpl.nasa.gov/multimedia/images/PIA14703_750_equi+CL.jpg), I created a mesh heightfield (2 mm max height), then created an oblate spheroid that matched the approximate ratio of equatorial vs polar diameters of vesta based on the still equatorial images. The spheroid's major diameter should be based on dividing the length of the mesh along its long axis (equatorial circumference) by pi to get the diameter. The mesh is then positioned above the spheroid, aligned in the center and the ApplyUVNMesh command wraps it around the body. I then smoothed it (UVN 0.1 ratio) just to get rid of some of the weirder cliff edges, exported it as an stl and then used meshlab to get rid of a lot of non-manifold thingies. It now prints very cleanly although the north pole (bottom) is flat because of limited data from that region. This technique will ONLY work for relativel;y regular differentiated bodies. Trying it on something oddly shaped like asteroid Kleopatra, Toutatis or a comet and you'll cry. Promise. But you can download flat projected maps of almost all planets and moons from the USGS and start making a collection of small globes using this technique - next I'm trying Europa.

title: Parametric Seej Penny Catapult (all parts in single stl)

description.text:
This penny catapult derived from that in the 2013 Seej Starter Set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116450) has all components in a single stl file for printing convenience (including some added pieces of ammo which kids can safely play with in the vicinity of your tv set). The catapult itself and the length of the atlas component can be scaled, the latter resulting in a different launching inclination and trajectory height. The provided stl files:
  • the original penny catapult with all components in a single file for printing convenience (printing surface is 131x128 mm)
  • a scaled up penny catapult (factor 1.4) with a slightly longer atlas component (factor 1.1) for a higher trajectory (printing surface 181x177 mm; it just fits on my Mendel's bed)
    • The provided zip file contains all Zheng3's original stl files and an openscad file which includes these and allows you to set the scaling factors yourself.

This is for use with SonnyLowe's Y mod for the Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3, which you can find here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1278055 I am using this plate on top of the openbuilds Y gantry plate to add some rigidity to the rather soft folger tech aluminum plate. In spite of the added thickness, the 2080 rail mod lowers the print bed slightly, so no overall print height is lost. This plate adds enough clearance to allow the full 200mm range of movement even if the rail is only as long as the printer frame (405mm). The added thickness also insures the bed doesn't hit the endstop before the gantry. The large holes on one side are slightly larger because the screws on one side of the gantry move in the elliptical mounts as you tighten the wheels to the rail. For V3, I reduced the fillets in the inside corners and made the center part wider than earlier versions, which allows for more endstop mounting options. The V4 file has recessed holes for the mount to the gantry. This means you can mount the gantry plate to this bed support plate with the 4 screws in the center holes, then put it on the rail, fit the belt etc., and then after everything is installed and adjusted, attach the folger tech aluminum plate, using just the 4 holes out on the arms. The ability to attach and remove the plate after everything else is assembled and on the printer makes installation and maintenance much easier. Otherwise the plate is in the way of adjusting the belt and gantry, making everything much more inconvenient.

comments.text: Is the thickness of the plate critical?
comments.author: jabu32

comments.text: The thickness increases the rigidity of the plate, but you can make it thinner, as long as you leave room for the heads of any bolts you want in the recesses.  Increasing fill density may also offset making it thinner, but the basic geometry of vertical thickness is part of what makes it stiff.  A thinner plate will always flex more.  It is just a matter of how much flex you are ok with, since the whole point of it was stiffness.  A secondary point was raising the bed plate enough to clear the front and rear mounts on the center bar, which may also be an issue of you go too thin.
comments.author: jabu32

comments.text: Will this support a 200 x 300 bed?
comments.author: Rillion

comments.text: Well, it was designed to print on a 200 x 200 bed.  It should hold a 200 x 300 bed, but won't extend nearly as far toward the corners as it would on a 200 x 200 bed.  That leaves more room for flex on a larger bed, but if you mounted the larger bed directly on the gantry plate, that would be even less support.  Even for a longer bed, it should be better than just mounting it directly to the gantry plate.
comments.author: Rillion

comments.text: I'll give it a shot.  Do you have the precise distance apart measurements for the bed mounting holes?  I want to be sure they line up with my bed.
comments.author: QuadBert

comments.text: I don't remember exactly.  I just laid it on the bottom of the aluminum plate and centered it, clamped it down, and drilled the holes.

author: mingofmongo

description.text:
After many months of hard work in the machine shop, on the computer, and at the good ole electronics workstation I am finally releasing my custom built Delta 3D Printer. Every part of the printer was hand designed and fabricated by me, though parts of the printer were certainly influenced by other printers on the market. The basis for my delving into this was that i wanted a relatively inexpensive, rather large build volume, fast and accurate 3D printer that was reliable and easy to repair. But the issue with that is that there are very few printers on the market that have all of those features, but also are under $500-600, which was my total budget for building this printer. Soon I plan on starting a full fledged 3D Printing company where Me and my Coworkers will fabricate and sell this very 3D printer, i'll be it with a few higher end fabrication techniques, and hopefully by the end of 2016 Dimension 3 Printing will help contribute to the amazing community and field of 3D printing! For the main structure of the printer I used 25mm 80-20 Aluminum extrusions, which are modeled and downloadable for your convenience. On the electronics end of it all I initially went with an Arduino Mega 2560 running a Ramps 1.4 board with Pololu stepper drivers. Since then i have converted to the Azteeg X5 Mini, which is a 32 bit controller, much better for all the delta kinematics. I have also outfitted the printer with 3D Printed carriages that use openbuilds wheels to run along the grooves in the extrusion, providing a very locked in linear movement system. I found that Openbuilds wheels are WELL WORTH their cost as they provide some of the most rock-solid and smooth movement that i have used. The build volume on the printer is approximately 300mm in the X&Y and 430mm in the Z direction. As for the extruder i went with a rather unique method of using a Flying extruder paired with an E3D V6 hot end and a NEMA 17 motor connected to an internal gearing system to drive it all. I have found that this works awesome for most things, especially for the simplicity and the ability to print flexible filaments. The flying extruder setup is basically a system of suspending the extruder motor a few inches above the hot end with some latex tubing, then running a very short length of ptfe tubing to the hot end from the extruder. By doing it this way you more evenly distribute the weight of the extruder over the arms of the printer, instead of having it all centered. This makes for cleaner, and faster printing. I used 1/8" id and .35" od latex tubing paired with the printable parts and some zip straps to very securely suspend the extruder motor. The photos above should clear up any confusion of how everything is setup. Not all of the files are printable, as a portion of them are parts that I purchased then modeled to ensure a perfect fit. Because of this I will be soon releasing detailed instructional videos as well as an intuitive instructional guide on my website, Dimension3printing.com, detailing nearly every portion of the construction and assembly of the printer. This includes the electronics, mechanics, and aesthetics of the machine. There is also included a .ZIP file that has all of the STL files organised into folders that help immensely with the printing and assembly process. If you are actually planning on attempting to build this epic machine I would say that the ZIP file is an absolute MUST! I also have seperate Thingiverse pages for each of the parts of the printer, so feel free to look to there for more help on constructing the individual parts of this printer. This is a work in progress, and through the following months i will be constantly updating the design, as well as the instructions. Here is a link to a detailed parts list of the parts i used to build the printer. It is updated as i modify it, so it will only get better! Feel free to use it to find parts for your printers! https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1xr3XB-6PyDt0rJZ6fhlJ1sU11i4wlew2rB4MuShOpHQ/edit?usp=sharing Teaser Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EX2o5emcHi4 Website- http://Dimenson3fab.com Facebook- https://www.facebook.com/Dimension-3-Printing-1705719523009017/ If anyone has any questions feel free to send me an email at [email protected], i would be happy to answer:) UPDATE 7-13-16 --------------------------------- Hello everyone! Thank you all so much for your continued questions, support, and interest in all of my designs. The past months have been very busy for me and my team, but through all of it we have continued to work hard to keep designing and pushing on! As of now I am working on finalizing the designs for a complete redesign of the printer that uses tons of openbuilds extrusions and linear rail as well as lots of printed and machined components to greatly increase the rigidity of the machine and also opening the door to the ability of the machine to do other more rigorous tasks such as CNC milling, and laser engraving. The overall plan is to soon offer kits and complete printers based off of the designs that will all of course be open source!
For more updates follow me on thingiverse, and check Dimension3 out on facebook at the links above! Happy Building everyone :) UPDATE 1-23-17 --------------------------------- Hello everyone, Over the past many months and thousands of hours of design time I am nearly ready to release the final version of my consumer version of the Dimension 3 MultiMachine Delta 3D Printer. Check it out at http://www.Dimension3fab.com

Printer:

Delta 3D Printer

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 or .1

Infill:

40%

Notes: For all of the parts i recommend to use around a 40% infill, as most parts will need rigidity to maintain decent tolerances while printing. Also all of the parts that i printed were printed with PLA, as it is a bit stiffer than ABS. Though if you have a heated print plate i would make sure that the parts that come close to it should be printed with ABS for temperature resistance. But if you know what works best for your printer than do that!

title: Star Wars X-wing: Jabba's Sail Barge

description.text:
"Khetanna" was the sail barge owned by the infamous crime lord Jabba the Hutt. I always thought this was a beautiful ship onscreen, even in its rusted condition. These files will allow Scum and Villainy faction players to add the Khetanna to their casual games of X-wing miniatures.
I envision it as a support ship, similar to the HWK. Since the deck gun can aim in every direction but straight out the back I would give it a 270 degree firing arc. I used pictures from the movie to get the proportions right. First you'll need to print the base. Note the 90 degree portion of the firing arc should be pointed backwards. Second, the ship itself. The hull is printed down and without supports. You might get a few stringers from the overhangs. I just clip them off but if you find this objectionable turn supports on.
You'll need two sails, printed with supports. Orient them with the most visible surface up so that the finished model looks best on the tabletop. The sails are very delicate so use care when removing the supports. You might notice a thicker portion down the center, which I added after I broke the first two I made.
The deck gun is printed with the base down, with supports. Happy gaming.

You are allowed (and encouraged) to print copies for your own personal use. title: HICTOP Prusa Extruder Fan Mount with Induction Probe

description.text:
May 2016: A second design has been uploaded. The original HICTOP blower has been replaced with a blower that work in 360 degrees. This is intended for HICTOP branded prusa i3 printers. This is to replace the original extruder fan mount with one that can mount an induction probe for auto leveling. I tried several other locations and found this solution to be the easiest to setup. It is stable and close to the extruder head. I've been using this for a long time now and it works great. I prints entirely without support. Notes:
Due to feedback, there are now two versions. The original upload was for a 12mm diameter induction probe (the one I use). 12mm probes have a 4mm sensing distance. Example probes include: LJ12A3-4-Z/BY (6v) and LJ12A3-4-Z/BX (12v). There are also probes that have a longer 8mm sensing distance. These are typically 18mm in diameter. Since I do not use one, I don't have examples to list, but there are many. I have also uploaded the editable (source) files. The models were created in Fusion360 (.f3d). I also uploaded a (.step) file for those who do not have Fusion 360. Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

HICTOP

No

No

Resolution:

I used 0.2

Infill:

I printed solid. 100%.

comments.text: This is my first time setting up aftermarket auto-leveling. Does someone know what the sensor offset is from the nozzle so I can get that into the program?
comments.author: Perseveranze

comments.text: There is no one magic number with this.  It will be dependent on your particular install.  Also, you're not going to be able to measure it accurately with calipers.  It is easy to determine, but it is going to be a bit of trial and error.  Here's a good method.  Heat up your extruder to printing temp and heat up the bed to printing temp (very important to do this with the printer heated up. Get a sheet of printer paper 0.1mm thick.  Lower your extruder all the way until it touches your print bed. Then slide your Z probe up until it no longer triggers (visual LED off).  Then slide the probe down just a tad past the point it first triggers (LED on).  You want it as high as possible above the extruder tip, but low enough it will trigger EVERY TIME.  With a 4mm probe, the Z offset is usually 1mm or under.  With an 8mm probe, it can be 2mm or under.  With the probe now installed a X height, it is time to figure out X (the Z probe offset).  In the firmware, set the Z offset number to a safe arbitrary distance, shooting a bit higher then what you think it really is.  Then with the setting saved in firmware, home your printer (all axis) with the sheet of printer paper on the bed.  If the paper moves freely, the Z offset is too high.  Slowly lower the offset setting in firmware until the sheet of paper just starts to have friction.  The sheet should move, but with a bit of traction.  You extrude tip is now just a tad higher than 0.1mm above the print bed with the Z offset determined.  Hope that helps.  .  FYI, in Repetier Firmware, the Z probe offset can be configured in the LCD (no computer) using a setting called Bed Coating Thickness.  This is how I currently configure my printers very quickly.
comments.author: Perseveranze

comments.text: What you are describing is the z-axis offset between the bed and the sensor. That I understand. What I'm asking for is the offset on the X and Y axis from the sensor to the extruder end. Since the extruder end and the sensor are in a fixed location to each other, there is a measurable distance that I need to enter into the firmware. I was hoping someone who printed this had that information. I may have to do it myself since I have a 4-day weekend starting tomorrow.

comments.text: Hi Strider thank you for the quick reply, I need to pick your brains again, i just purchased a new proximity sensor to replace the inductive one that came with the printer, the new one has the brown tip & has a range of 1-10mm. The wires on my inductive sensor are the same colour as those on my new sensor, the inductive sensor has a dedicated socket on the atmega2560 ramps board. Would it be possible to just wire the small plug from the inductive to the proximity sensor & plug that into the board, the output of the sensor is 6-36v. Oh & the psu on the printer is 24v.
comments.author: Ruckinhell09

comments.text: The new sensor you described is the exact same one I have on one of my printers.  My printer is older then yours (did not come with a proxy sensor to begin with).  This is how I have mine hooked up.  Brown wire connected to power supply 24V+ (pigtailed).  Blue wire to power supply ground.  Black wire (single wire) connected to Z min endstop Pin 1.   If I were you, I would check to ensure that the sensor is being powered from the power supply vs being powered from an Arduino 5V pin.   I don't know exactly what board pins your old sensor were hooked up to, but my sensor connects to the board with just a single pin/wire (Z min). One thing to look out for is if you have a Normally Open sensor or a Normally Closed sensor.  If your sensor LED only lights when it senses, its a normally open type (shouldn't require a firmware update).  If your LED is always lit and goes out when it senses, its normally closed (a firmware change is likely needed)..
comments.author: Ruckinhell09

comments.text:
Can you tell me where to find Z min endstop pin 1. I have trawled the internet for answers but can find none.
Thanks
comments.author: Lay3rWorks

comments.text: Your Z- endstop (port) should be labeled right on the board.  If not, the board specs (online) should clearly label it.  It may have two-three pins total.  Then, as for which one to plug the Z probe into, it is okay to guess through trial and error.  With the printer on, Z axis raised high, the Z probe powered, plug the data pin of the probe into one of the Z min pins.  Most likely the far left.  Get a metal tool, home Z, and quickly wave the metal under the probe to trigger it.  Z homing should stop.  If not, reset the printer and try the next pin.  This is a crude approach, but will work.
comments.author: Ruckinhell09

description.text: It's a pretty simple double sided bottle opener. you can either pop it with a smile or twist it. Have fun!

The Bantha II cargo skiffs that accompany Jabba the Hutt's sail barge on excursions into the Dune Sea. These files allow Scum and Villainy faction players another ship to use in casual games of X-wing. Unlike the lumbering sail barge, these are relatively fast but lightly armed and very easy to destroy. The standard issue transports are built unarmed but Jabba weaponized his with blasters. First, you'll need a base. The skiff is pretty small so I made a custom post to hold it. Unfortunately it means you need to glue the skiff to the base. Second, the skiff itself. The hull is printed without supports. You'll need one of each of the wings, which are printed flat and without support as well. Since these models are so small I printed them at high resolution and they still took only a few minutes each.
Super-glue them in place before painting. Once in place they were surprisingly strong, so that was a win. I think they would look better with people riding in them, so I'll probably add those files at some point. Happy gaming.

Manufactured by the Corellian Mining Corporation as giant, mobile field offices for mining operations.  Abandoned by their original owners, they were re-purposed by clans of Jawas as mobile homes.  These files will allow X-wing players to use them in casual/scenario games.  Let's face it, you'll probably use /this/ model as background scenery or as target practice for TIE fighters, but I did include a standard large ship base should you need it.
I used pictures of the movie model to get the proportions right and a few other fan-made models for other details.  I was surprised at the size of it, it's a big model in terms of X-wing minis (over 5" long).  Printing is very straightforward: tracks down, no supports.  Hull flat on the build plate, no supports.
Happy gaming.

I have a Yashica 635, a small TLR camera which has the awesome ability to shoot booth 35mm and 120mm film. I have several other medium format cameras such as a Holga 120CFN, and Holga 120WPC that I wanted to adapt to take 35mm.   
Lomography sells a kit that consits of a new camera backplate, and film mask that goes inside the camera. They don't however give you a good way to suspend the film inside the camera. Many creative solutions are out there including styrofoam packing peanuts, or small pieces of foam, but I always worry about particulate generation.  
The spacers fit into the holes of a 35mm film cannister, and the take up spool keeps that vertical alignment consistent throughout the roll of film  
These 3 parts are meant to supplement the kit from logography. You don't need the kit, but will have to cover the red window on the back of the Holga or risk exposing all the film that you shoot. And use the regular 6x6 film mask.
Print and shoot!

title: DNA repair enzyme MutS from E. coli

description.text: The machinery that copies DNA makes an error approximately every 10 million bases. That may not seem like much if you are a bacterium that only has 5 million bases in its genome, but if you replicate once per hour, then on average half of your descendants have a mutation, and this number rapidly approaches 100% as you near the end of the day. It stands to reason, then, that E coli needs something more than just proofreading polymerases to keep its DNA from mutating, and that is where the mismatch repair protein MutS fits in. MutS clamps on to the mismatched base pairing and recruits other proteins that perform the repair. Read more here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MutS-1

I got this model from PDB structure 3zlj.   
Printed using KISSlicer, 0.15 layer height and 0.5mm extrusion width, 15% infill and with the support flow rate decreased to 75% by an external script.

title: YAZA - yet another Z switch adjuster (Ultimaker)

description.text:
This is probably one of the most useful, yet simple designs I did for the ultimaker, in addition to the XY "bananas blocks". You can read about the list of improvements on http://www.tridimake.com/2014/01/features-and-improvements-for-a-homemade-ultimaker.html
This one makes life easier for sure. Fine-tuning the level of the Z end switch is a chronic issue, especially as you switch among different nozzles or bed thicknesses.
In this design, the carriage slides tightly in two concave rails of the outer frame, which is secured on the case by four outer screws. There is NO way the carriage can move otherwise than vertically, as it should. Neither the carriage nor the micro-switch do touch the plywood for a fluid movement.
Most of what I have tried so far proved to be unreliable in this regard, probably because of something that (tried to) slide against the internal plywood wall. The only parts here that are in contact with the printer walls are the fixed parts.
I designed it for an Ultimaker, but it easily adapts to others. The openscad source code is included as usual, in case a change is needed (here is a very easy tutorial if you need it: http://www.tridimake.com/2014/09/how-to-use-openscad-tricks-and-tips-to.html)

The main screw I used a long M4 screw (actually a threaded rod), about 60mm long. Insert it through the hole of the top horizontal bar of the frame, then screw nuts on each side, by leaving just enough room so the whole screw + nuts rotate as a whole without any vertical play.
These nuts can be glued to the screw (as I did, after willingly damaging the thread a bit with a pair of cutting pliers), or you may use two pairs of nut and counter nut instead on each side of the top bar (as the openscan screenshot, a bulkier solution). Both ways are better that using nylocks, which would eventually slip and start to move on the thread in the long term. Note that you could use an M3 screw for less travel per turn (in which case you'll have to change the value in the openscad source code). In my opinion, M4 is a good trade off when you change your printing bed often, because it's faster to tune with an M4. I used my thumbnut design for the screw head, which can be customized at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:70494 I chose small diameter and wings so that I can turn it quickly between my thumb and index fingers. How to mount the rail frame
The nut holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44118) was quite useful to help fixing the Z adjuster rail on the printer frame. Just make sure how you mount the adjuster. The head should protrude from the top of your frame: either use a sufficiently long M4, or use a threaded rod cut at the appropriate length (as I did here in the actual device). Mine goes up a bit too much I guess. You could also use a regular screw with existing head, then use a screwdriver to tune the Z. In this case you do not even need the screw head to protrude from the top of your printer. The carrier hole is tight, so you can screw the threaded rod directly by force (use quick forth/back movement to tap the hole when needed), but you can glue screws around or heat-sink them in the carrier if you really need it. Just make sure that the carrier slides as a nut would on the threaded rod when you rotate the latter. The micro-switch is screwed to the carrier from the other side and though the wall of the printer. Just use screws long enough for the thickness of your printer wall. The two slabs on the carriers are there to prevent squeezing the microswitch and carrier too much against the walls, but do not tighten the screws too much (the microswitch must be allowed to slide vertically without much effort, being held by the carrier on the other side of the printer). Finally, you can prevent lateral freeplay on the carrier thanks to the outer oblong holes on the frame. The best way to proceed is to slide the carrier at the same level as the fixing frame holes, so you know how much pinching you need before yhe screws are tightened on the printer frame. Then, move the carrier to the height of the other pair of frame screws and secure them again. Actually, no piching was required in my case, as the design is already tight (and in any case, horizontal movements have no impact on the end result, only vertical sloppiness would have). In the end, it will only be 4 more holes in your printer frame. I did not measure the screw length, but they are quite common and you'll sort it out easily. Hope you like it and that it makes your hobbyist life easier :)

comments.text: When you say "extra long" M4 How long are we talking? Longest I could find at Home Depot was 40mm, but that doesn't seem like it would be long enough. I haven't printed this yet to compare..

comments.text:
I used it for about 2 years with no wear at all. Usually the tuning is minimalist, only when I (rarely) change the print bed itself. But I could not turn it as fast as to melt the plastic anyway even if I tried.
A captive nut could be added if you really want to make sure, but actually I favor direct threading in PLA or ABS because they leave really no play at all, which is desirable. Avoid Nylon as it tends to expand with moisture tho!
Cheers - jeremie

comments.author: Hyphen1

comments.text:
Hi Rick! You reminded me of someone years ago, and yes, you are the one who derived my end caps with a bat-symbol :D
Sorry, I am no native speaker, and this was done even before I practiced again my english ;)
Yes it really works flawlessly. Check the last picture where the yaza is fully assembled: the top two nuts should not move on the thread. They rotate as a whole with the screw. The screw itself should be able to rotate freely into the frame (top hole).
So you may glue the two nuts on the thread on each side of the frame top bar, or you can pinch (or "damage") the thread where they are located so they will not want to rotate on the screw due to friction on the top frame. You can also use pairs of nut and counter nut (locked on each other), one pair for each side of the top frame bar, as shown in the openscad overall preview (the one with colors).

title: Folger i3 2020 Z-Axis Induction Sensor and Fan Bracket

description.text: Bracket to hold a cooling fan (See Thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1161013 for the fan shroud) and inductive sensor on my Folger 2020 Prusa i3. OpenSCAD file included but requires the .stl from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1161013 Added new .STL and OpenSCAD files for an 18mm version. One about the same as the original 12mm but pulled in as close to the printhead as I could get it. And a second version I haven't printed yet with the ring pulled back in the Y axis so it will clear my binder clips better the bottom thickened for more strength and tried to make it look cleaner. If you grabbed the new big-back.scad file before I'm putting this notice up - it probably won't work. I had to add a bit more clearance between the loop and the extruder. I've uploaded the replacement file and the print of it is what's shown installed in green.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Folger 2020 Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: I printed this in PETG since I like it better than ABS, but ABS should be fine as well. I wouldn't suggest PLA since this mounts right against the cold break and heatsink of the extruder, but the designer of the bracket I based this on said he used a PLA version successfully. Original inductive bracket suggested printing with 100% infill, but the fan bracket I based this off is more substantial than the inductive bracket so I just went with 30% and it seems plenty strong. I've printed and used both the 12mm and 18mm versions in PETG and ABS. Even when my printer was having overhang/bridging issues I was able to print this with no supports.

I made this in OpenSCAD by importing the bracket from Thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1161013 The loop for the inductive sensor I added manually based on measurements from Thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:671600 with a small stretched cube to attach it. I expected the fan bracket part to need support, but when I sliced it slic3r with supports enabled it didn't add any - it did however add some to the right mounting block so I went back in and added a cube under that so it could print without any support.

comments.text: Do you still require the resistor setup on 12v?  My understanding with the latest Marlin firmware is that software enabled pull up resistor settings per endstop remove the physical resistor requirements.  Is that correct?
comments.author: Jgrant50

comments.text: I'm running Marlin 1.1.0-RC6 (and have been for close to two months now) and still have my resistors to keep the voltage in check.  Theoretically with an NPN sensor like this it should be ok without because the Mega board isn't sourcing the current...but I'd rather play things safe and not risk trying the mega.  With the dropping resistors the voltage is in the 3-5v range so no risk to the mega and still works great.  Since I had the resistors on hand and it only took a few minutes to solder them in they're cheap insurance even if they may not be strictly required.
comments.author: Jgrant50

comments.text: 1/2 watt vs. 1/4 watt?  You'd be fine with 1/4 watt.  1/2 watt would work as well, but would be bigger.  There's almost no current so the amount of power being dissipated is very low.  Pretty sure I used 1/4 watt resistors on mine since I have more 1/4 watt on hand than 1/2 watt.

This is the first attempt at making a lenshood for the canon 18-55 kitlens. It is still a work in progress, but I wanted to share the preliminary results. The little notch on the bajonet needs to be smaller and probably placed differently.I removed them with pliers so the lenshood would fit. Also the ultimaker printed the hood as two layers which didn't completely adhere.I guess this has to do with the settings of the ultimaker which I'm still very new to. Hope to inspire some and perhaps improve on this initial desing. Gicks UPDATE
Version 2 is up! I removed the notch on the bayonet fitting because the fitting is snug enough without it. I changed the thickness of the model from 1.2 mm to 1.0mm so that the two printed lines(inner and outer wall) are much closer together. This improved the overall stiffness of the model.

I'm new to the 3d printing thing so I'll just share some of the settings I used. I printed on the Ultimaker, running the 5d firmware.
Using:Replicator G 25 beta and Skeinforge 35, profile: Ultimaker failsafe V1. Layer height: 0.3mm

title: iPhone 5s Case with Japanese Traditional Pattern

description.text:
Makerbot Replicator 2X and ABS 日本伝統の「麻の葉」文様です。
周りをへこませた、オリジナルデザインである「)(（ジェミニ）デザイン」は、意外と手になじみます。指の腹がちょうどへこみに合うので、落としづらくなると同時に、仮に落としてもその分厚みがあるために衝撃を吸収します。
とはいえ、実際何回かポケットから落としてますが、ケースにヒビ入ることはあっても、iPhone本体には傷一つ付いていません。
液晶面の全周をガードしているので、どの角度でも液晶の破損を防ぐためと思われます。上部と下部が空いているデザインだと、そこから落ちるとノーガードで液晶に衝撃が伝わります。
おそらくiPhoneSEにも合うはず。iPhone SEにもピッタリはまります。 v803では意図的なサポートを削除しました。外枠を少し薄くしたのでハメやすくなっています。麻の葉文様の目を荒く、線を細くしました。 v54まではサイズが厳密すぎたので、若干クリアランスを設定したのがv73です。
Lightningとイヤホンジャックの間を埋めた関係で、下のツメが逆にはめにくくなりましたが、裏からマイナスドライバーなどでツメをちょっと押してあげるとハマります。
以前のバージョンには、Lightningなどの穴の辺りに意図的なサポーターを加えてあります。
印刷後に削り取ってください。 iPhone 5s Case
with Support. After print out, remove it.
Pattern is Japanese traditional one it is called "Asa no Ha". Lucky pattern.
If the rumor is true, this case will fit iPhoneSE too.
This case fits with iPhone SE! v803 has thin frame and thin pattern.
New version has more clearance. It is easy to put on.

title: Magnetic levitation
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A bar is levitated using 10x10mm cylindrical neodymium magnets. The neodymium magnets are so strong that the floater is levitated by 3 cm. It will look good at your office desk and can also be a good scientific toy for the kids. Additional things required:
  • 10mmx10mm cylindrical (disc) neodymium magnets - 6 pieces (you can also use set of 5 pieces of 10mmx2mm magnets in place of each 10mmx10mm magnet)
  • A piece of thread
    • Print instructions:
    Print to the scale, if the scale is changed, the magnets don't fit in. I printed with 15% fill and i think its not a crucial factor. Assembly Instructions:
    The magnets snap fit in to the slots on the base. All the similar poles (either north pole or south pole) of all 6 magnest should face in the same direction as shown in the last image. The magnets should not be exactly on top of base magnets but should be displaced approximately by 10mm. Important note: Don't place the levitating kit on a magnetic material like a metal table or a metal plate. The metal will interfere with magnetic field created by magnets and the rod will loose balance and won't levitate.
